These priorities rarely get much attention, since they are bureaucratic. But they are a huge deal. More here: https://t.co/OmHr3yvoFH
That's a big break from Trump's previous commitment to only target undocumented immigrants who are dangerous or threaten the public.
It also includes hundreds of thousands of people who have received a final removal order but haven't left the country. Many are families.
That includes undocumented immigrants convicted of any crime or having simply been charged -- not convicted -- of a crime.
Trump's order yesterday makes many, many more people considered priorities, putting them in the crosshairs for deportation.
After the priorities were revised in 2014, nearly 90% of undocumented immigrants were no longer considered priorities for deportation.
These priorities tell who immigration officials should target—and who they should leave alone. They were first created under Obama in 2010.
One of the most important parts Trump's EO on immigration has gotten little attention: new enforcement priorities https://t.co/OmHr3yvoFH

The Heritage budget has a very detailed rundown for the discretionary spending cuts. A page on each program with justification for cuts.
I'm comparing to more recent CBO numbers, so these will be off from what Heritage says in the report. But they give you a sense of the cuts
By my calcs, Heritage cuts about - $600 billion from Social Security - $3.2 trillion from Medicare - $2.5 trillion from rest of mandatory

As antitrust becomes a bigger issue, it's worth remembering that horizontal mergers appear to hurt consumers more than vertical ones

Why? Largely because the strong economy gave workers leverage to demand higher wages. This is hugely important. Trump misses it.
But he also ignores real improvements post-recession and, more importantly, overlooks that the late '90s saw a large drop in black poverty.
Trump paints an extraordinarily negative picture of black America. And black poverty rates remain far higher than those of white Americans.
Both of those claims are false. I went into the CPS microdata to debunk them: https://t.co/vD1yibGZUy

On Monday, he said that 45% of black youths live in poverty.
